name: 1,3,5,7-Cyclooctatetraene

energies.comment: NON-AROMATIC (avoids antiaromaticity). Has 8 π-electrons (4n, n=2) which would be antiaromatic if planar, but adopts NON-PLANAR 'tub' conformation to prevent full π-conjugation. Shows +84 kJ/mol positive violation - the tub form is slightly MORE stable than expected for localized polyene, likely due to favorable geometry. If forced planar, would be strongly antiaromatic (>200 kJ/mol destabilization). Critical test: larger ring with 4n electrons that AVOIDS antiaromaticity through geometry.
energies.source: Prosen et al., J. Res. NBS 1950; NIST Chemistry WebBook
energies.confidence_note: Experimental heat of formation from combustion calorimetry. Value calculated from liquid phase + vaporization enthalpy. Non-planar structure well-established by X-ray crystallography and spectroscopy.

reference_energies.comment: Standard bond energies (kJ/mol) for naive calculation. Naive = 4(C=C) + 4(C-C) + 8(C-H) = 4(602) + 4(346) + 8(413) = 7096 kJ/mol

notes: Cyclooctatetraene (COT) has 8 π-electrons: 4n where n=2, would be antiaromatic if planar
AVOIDS antiaromaticity by adopting non-planar 'tub' (or 'boat') conformation with D2d symmetry
This prevents all p-orbitals from aligning → no continuous π-conjugation → non-aromatic, not antiaromatic
Energy cost to flatten COT: ~50-100 kJ/mol to overcome ring strain + antiaromatic destabilization
Positive violation (+84 kJ/mol): tub form is slightly stabilized vs localized polyene
Comparison to benzene: benzene MUST be planar (aromatic), COT MUST NOT be planar (would be antiaromatic)
Critical insight: molecular geometry can 'opt out' of antiaromaticity when ring is large enough
Tests hypothesis: large rings can avoid electronic correlation feedback by breaking planarity
Contrast with cyclobutadiene: 4-membered ring too small to escape planarity → forced antiaromaticity
For feedback loop hypothesis: COT shows that PLANAR cycles amplify correlation, non-planar can decouple
